newsitem.title: GERMANY: German IBIS DAX ends above crucial 2,800 level.
newsitem.headline: German IBIS DAX ends above crucial 2,800 level.

text.p: German shares climbed to new record highs on Monday, boosted by strength in the dollar, which benefits German exporters, and gains in bourse newcomer Deutsche Telekom.
The German DAX index of 30 top shares ended floor trade at a record bourse level of 2,799.19 points, up 35.50 points, or 1.28 percent, just above an all-time high of 2,799.05 reached on November 15.

After the bourse close the DAX mounted the psychological and technical level of 2,800 points to touch a new record high in IBIS computer dealings of 2,805.75 points, before closing at 2,800.52 up 31.05 points.

Shares in telecommunications giant Telekom ended up three percent, or 96 pfennigs at 32.98 marks. Dealers said an initial wave of speculative profit-taking had come to an end, with the stock also recovering somewhat in Friday's New York trade.
"Players like how the shares stablised last week and are now ready to take positions," said one dealer.

The chemical and carmaker sectors were helped by the firmer dollar, which rose nearly a pfennig on its Friday closing level, firmly above 1.51 marks. After the close of share dealings the dollar rally continued above 1.52 marks.
Dealers said the re-entry of the Italian lira into the European Exchange Rate Mechanism was also positive for German exporting stocks as it made monetary union seem more likely.
"The entry of the lira into the ERM makes the Euro seem more like a concrete reality," said one dealer.
Meanwhile, shares in electronics giant Siemens were the only DAX stock to end bourse dealings in negative territory, falling 66 pfennigs to 70.87 marks.
Dealers said the stock was experiencing a delayed reaction to figures released last week at Siemens Nixdorf Informationsssysteme AG, the company's computer unit.
